title: Daily Evening Bhagavatam Discourse | HH Stoka Krishna Swami | SB 1.13.28 | 10-10-2022
speaker: HH Stoka Krishna Swami

segments.key_quote: In this session we will be discussing from the 28th verse of the 13th chapter of the 1st canto of Srimad Bhagavatam
segments.summary: The speaker begins with prayers and introduces the topic of discussion: verse 28 of chapter 13, canto 1 of Srimad Bhagavatam.

segments.key_quote: Please therefore leave for the north immediately, without letting your relatives know, for soon that time will approach, which will diminish the good qualities of men.
segments.summary: The speaker explains the context of the verse, focusing on Vidura's instruction to Dhritarashtra to leave for the north due to the approaching age of Kali and its deteriorating effects on human qualities.

segments.key_quote: The age referred to here is the age of Kali which is fast approaching.
segments.summary: The speaker elaborates on Srila Prabhupada's explanation of the verse, emphasizing the imminent arrival of Kali Yuga and its characteristic degradation of human qualities.

segments.key_quote: A conditioned soul is already degraded by the material association whether Satya Yuga or Dwapar Yuga or Treta Yuga or Kali Yuga.
segments.summary: The speaker continues to discuss the degradation caused by material association in all Yugas, with Kali Yuga representing the lowest point, and Dhritarashtra's need to leave home before its full influence sets in.

segments.key_quote: Human life is simply meant for self realization, but due to this dangerous age, men have completely forgotten the aim of life.
segments.summary: The speaker describes symptoms of Kali Yuga, including the forgetting of self-realization as the aim of life and the prevalence of unrestricted sense gratification.

segments.key_quote: In this age of Kali, the life span will gradually decrease, people will gradually lose their memory, they will lose their finer sentiments, they will lose their strength, and they will lose their better qualities.
segments.summary: The speaker details the negative consequences of Kali Yuga, such as decreased lifespan, loss of memory and finer sentiments, and the complete absorption in sense gratification, leading to the neglect of self-realization.

segments.key_quote: The whole system of education in Kali Yuga is geared to sense gratification.
segments.summary: The speaker contrasts the current education system, focused on sense gratification, with the traditional gurukula system, which emphasized self-realization and livelihood training.

segments.key_quote: Learned men therefore must be cautious of this age, and if they at all want to cross over the dangerous ocean of Kali, they must follow the footsteps of great saintly persons.
segments.summary: The speaker advises caution in Kali Yuga and suggests following the guidance of saintly persons and scriptures like Bhagavad Gita and Srimad Bhagavatam to cross the ocean of material existence.

segments.key_quote: A person who is completely relieved of all taints of sinful acts can alone depend on the Supreme Lord Sri Krishna.
segments.summary: The speaker explains that Vidura's instruction to Dhritarashtra is tailored to his situation, highlighting the difficulty of becoming a Narottama (first-class devotee) for ordinary people due to sinful acts, referencing Bhagavad Gita 7.28.

segments.key_quote: Dhritarashtra is advised by Vibhira to at least become a Dheera.
segments.summary: The speaker outlines three stages of spiritual advancement - Dheera, Sanyasi, and Narottama - and emphasizes that becoming a Dheera (one who is detached) is the minimum requirement for preparing for death and self-realization, concluding with a summary of Vidura's advice to Dhritarashtra.
